document: This file reviews key concepts of NP‑completeness, dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, and the P vs NP question.

questions.question: Dynamic programming relies on optimal substructure.
Greedy algorithms always guarantee a globally optimal solution for every problem.
A Hamiltonian cycle is an example of an NP‑complete problem.
The class P consists of problems that can be solved in exponential time.
If any one NP‑complete problem could be solved in polynomial time, then every problem in NP could be solved in polynomial time.
A nondeterministic computer can guess a solution and must verify it within polynomial time.
The Halting Problem is in the class P.
Reducibility means that one problem can be translated into another so that a solution to the latter yields a solution to the former.
Traveling Salesman Problem is known to have a polynomial‑time algorithm for all graphs.
Knapsack problem is one of the classic NP‑complete problems.
Dynamic programming problems always involve overlapping subproblems.
Greedy algorithms are usually harder to implement than dynamic programming solutions.
The class NP contains problems that can be solved in polynomial time by a deterministic Turing machine.
A solution found by a nondeterministic computer is guaranteed to be correct if it exists.
Polynomial‑time algorithms are defined as running in O(n^k) for some constant k.
An NP‑complete problem is always easier than an arbitrary NP problem.
Dynamic programming solutions never use tables to store subproblem results.
